title: How to Use an Overripe Tomato

steps.headline: Score the tomatoes.
steps.description: Turn each tomato over and use a sharp knife to cut a shallow X into the bottom of each fruit. This will help the skin to peel off easier after you boil and cool the tomatoes.

steps.headline: Boil the tomatoes for 60 seconds.
steps.description: Fill a large pot with water and bring it to a boil over medium-high heat. When the water is boiling, drop the tomatoes into the water with a slotted spoon. Bring the water back to a boil and cook the tomatoes for a minute. Cooking the tomatoes like this will help to loosen the skins, making them easier to peel.

steps.headline: Plunge the tomatoes into an ice bath.
steps.description: Fill a large bowl halfway with ice, and fill the bowl the rest of the way with cold water. Remove the tomatoes from the boiling water with the slotted spoon and transfer them to the ice bath. Leave the tomatoes in the cold water for 60 seconds. Dunking the tomatoes in the ice water will immediately stop the cooking process, and help the tomatoes to retain more color once they're cooked.

steps.headline: Peel off the skins.
steps.description: Use the slotted spoon to remove the tomatoes from the ice water and transfer them to a cutting board. Turn the tomatoes over to the scored side and use your fingers to peel away the skin. Use a sharp knife to cut away any stubborn pieces of skin that don’t want to come off easily.

steps.headline: Seed and dice the tomatoes.
steps.description: Cut the tomatoes in half through the middle (not from stem to bottom). Use your finger to gently scoop out the seeds. Dice the seeded tomatoes into 1-inch (2.5 cm) cubes and transfer them to a large, heavy-bottomed saucepan.

steps.headline: Cook all the ingredients together for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Add the salt, sugar, parsley, and chopped green pepper to the pot with the tomatoes. Put on the lid and heat the mixture over medium heat. Bring the mixture to a simmer and cook it for half an hour, stirring regularly. Other vegetables you can add to the stewed tomatoes include chopped celery, onion, and garlic. You can add any dried herbs you like to the tomatoes, such as basil, rosemary, parsley, and oregano.

steps.headline: Sauté the onion and garlic.
steps.description: Pour the oil into a large, heavy-bottomed saucepan. Heat the oil over medium heat for 1 to 2 minutes, until the surface is shimmering. Add the onion and cook it for 2 to 3 minutes, until it’s soft and translucent. Add the garlic and sauté the mixture for an additional minute, until the garlic is fragrant.

steps.headline: Reserve half the onion and garlic.
steps.description: Divide the onion and garlic mixture into two equal parts. Remove half the mixture from the saucepan and transfer it to a heat-proof bowl. Set the bowl aside and return the saucepan to the heat.

steps.headline: Add the chopped tomatoes.
steps.description: Add the peeled and chopped tomatoes to the saucepan with the remaining onion and garlic mixture. Cook the tomatoes for about 5 to 8 minutes, until they're soft and tender.

steps.headline: Puree the mixture.
steps.description: Transfer the tomato mixture to a blender. Put the lid on the blender and remove the cap insert from the center of the lid. Cover the hole with a folded tea towel. Blend the tomato mixture until smooth, about 2 to 3 minutes. Set the blender aside. Removing the lid insert and covering it with a towel will prevent the heat from building up inside the blender and exploding. You can also leave the mixture in the saucepan and use an immersion blender to puree the tomatoes.

steps.headline: Cook the carrots with the reserved onion and garlic.
steps.description: Return the reserved onion and garlic mixture to the saucepan. Add the carrots to the pan and cook them for about 5 minutes, until soft. You can use any chopped vegetables you like in place of or in addition to the carrots, such as peppers, mushrooms, zucchini, and eggplant.

steps.headline: Combine the carrots and the tomato puree.
steps.description: Pour the tomato puree back into the saucepan with the sautéed carrots. Put on a lid and bring the sauce to a simmer over medium heat. Leave the sauce to cook for 20 to 25 minutes to marry all the flavors. Remove the sauce from the heat. To add extra richness to the sauce, add a rind from a block of Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese. Simmer the rind for the full 20 to 25 minutes. Before serving the sauce, remove the rind with a slotted spoon.

steps.headline: Garnish with the herbs, vinegar, and seasonings before serving.
steps.description: Stir in the chopped basil, a splash of balsamic vinegar for extra tang, and salt and pepper, to taste. Stir the sauce to incorporate the final ingredients and serve with your favorite pasta or rice dishes.

methods.name: Finding Other Ways to Use Overripe Tomatoes

steps.headline: Make soup.
steps.description: Tomato soup is a warm, comforting, and delicious way to use overripe tomatoes. Making tomato soup is quite simple, and all you have to do is cook or roast some peeled tomatoes with aromatics like onions, add spices and broth, and blend until smooth. For a creamy tomato soup, add ⅓ cup (78 ml) of heavy cream and 1½ cups (353 ml) of broth per 28 ounces (794 g) of tomatoes. For aromatics, add an onion, two cloves of garlic, and salt and pepper. If you're not in the mood for tomato soup right now, you can also can homemade tomato soup and enjoy it later.

steps.headline: Roast them.
steps.description: Take any overripe tomatoes you want to use up and cut them in half. Arrange them in a single layer on a baking sheet with the cut-side up. Drizzle each half with olive oil, and season them with salt, pepper, garlic powder, or other seasonings of your choice, to taste. Roast the tomatoes in a 225 °F (107 °C) oven for three hours. Once the tomatoes are roasted, remove them from the oven and allow them to cool. When they're cool, the roasted tomatoes are ready to be eaten as is or added to other dishes, such as bruschetta.

steps.headline: Make a tomato vinaigrette.
steps.description:
Collect the juice from four tomatoes. Cut the tomatoes in half. Place one tomato half into a fine-mesh strainer positioned over a large bowl. Use the back of a spoon to push the tomato into the strainer. Repeat with the other halves. To make the vinaigrette:
Add equal parts olive oil to the tomato juice that you collected
Add a drizzle of balsamic vinegar, to taste, to the mixture
Season the dressing with salt, pepper, and other seasonings, to taste
Whisk the mixture together until smooth and emulsified

steps.headline: Simmer them to make jam.
steps.description:
You can spread tomato jam on toast and crackers just like you would with other fruit jams, but you can also use it as a condiment for meats, vegetables, and other dishes. There are many different types of tomato jam you can make, including:
Garlic and vinegar
Cinnamon and clove
Spicy pepper and paprika

steps.headline: Dry them.
steps.description: Dehydrated tomatoes are an amazing and zesty way to perk up a salad, pasta, risotto, and many other dishes. Cut the tomatoes into half-inch (13 mm) slices and arrange them in a single layer on dehydrator trays. Dehydrate the tomatoes slices for eight to 10 hours at 125 °F (52 °C), until they're dry and shrivelled. You can dehydrate tomatoes in the oven if you don’t have a dehydrator. Arrange the tomato slices on a baking sheet and cook them at 125 °F (52 °C), or on the lowest heat, until shrivelled.

steps.headline: Make tomato juice.
steps.description:
Tomato juice is wonderful and nutritious, and it’s also the basis for tasty cocktails like the Bloody Mary and the Caesar. You can make your own tomato juice at home, and all you have to do is chop some tomatoes roughly, heat them in a pot, and strain out the juice. You can even add seasonings to the juice to customize the flavor, and can add things like:
Sugar
Salt
Pepper
Celery salt
Garlic powder
Onion powder
Fresh or dried herbs

steps.headline: Strain them into tomato water.
steps.description: Roughly chop six tomatoes and then sprinkle them with a teaspoon (6 g) of salt. Puree the mixture in a blender or food processor. Line a fine-mesh strainer with cheesecloth or a coffee filter and pour the puree into the lined strainer. Let the mixture strain overnight, and in the morning, season the water with salt, pepper, cayenne, and other seasonings, to taste. You can add tomato water to cocktails, drizzle it on meats or seafoods, add it to potatoes, or combine it with other dishes to add extra richness and flavor.

steps.headline: Freeze them.
steps.description: Rinse the tomatoes under running water and scrub the skin with a cloth or vegetable brush. Dry the tomatoes with a towel. Use a sharp knife to remove the stem. Transfer the tomatoes to a freezer-safe container and press out all the air before sealing it. Place the tomatoes in the freezer flat, making sure they're not touching. Allow the tomatoes to freeze this way for at least six hours. Freezing the tomatoes flat and not touching will ensure they don’t freeze together. Frozen tomatoes will keep in the freezer for up to six months.
